summary: Mediastinal germ cell tumors are tumors that derive from germ cell rest remnants in the mediastinum. They are uncommon, representing only 3 to 10% of tumors originating in the mediastinum. Malignant mediastinal tumors are usually symptomatic at the time of diagnosis and cause symptoms by compressing or invading adjacent structures.
causes: Abnormal migration of germ cells during embryogenesis
Widespread distribution of germ cells to multiple sites during normal embryogenesis
symptoms: Compression of adjacent structures (lungs, pleura, pericardium, chest wall)
Invasion of adjacent structures (lungs, pleura, pericardium, chest wall)
diagnosis: CT of the chest and abdomen
Determination of serum levels of HCG
Determination of serum levels of alpha-fetoprotein
Biopsy (examination of tissue, cells, or fluids)
treatments: Chemotherapy using bleomycin, etoposide and cisplatin (for pure mediastinal seminomas)
Chemotherapy following surgical resection (for nonseminomatous germ cell tumors)
